0.58.text: Hi! My name is Bruce Muzik.

2.60.text: And whether or not you're in a relationship

4.37.text:
the next 15 minutes are going to be
important for you

7.72.text: Because you're about to learn secrets that most smart people never learn...

11.55.text:
about what it takes to make romantic
relationships really work.

15.58.text:
We'll take a look at why you have attracted
your romantic partner?

18.78.text: And if you're single right now,

20.20.text: why you have attracted the romantic partners you have in the past?

22.62.text: And it's not what you think it's going to be.

24.48.text: We're also going to take a look at the five stages that your romantic relationship is going to need to go through...

29.92.text:
if you want to create long-term
connection, stability, security and love.

36.02.text: We are going to  look at which stage you are most likely to get stuck at, and what to do if you do.

41.22.text:
Finally, we are going to take a look at what
to do

43.66.text: once the blissful feelings of falling in love begin to fade.

47.50.text: As they so often do in long-term romantic relationships.

51.24.text: So if you and I haven't met before... I'm Bruce.

54.52.text: I'm originally from South Africa currently living in the Caribbean

57.55.text: Hence the palm trees behind me.

59.34.text: And I'm really passionate about helping smart people like you

62.32.text: build unbreakable bonds with your romantic partner

66.08.text:
and helping you experience all the joy,
the connection, the intimacy,

70.56.text:
and the freedom that a romantic
relationship that works has to offer.

74.78.text:
Without settling, without compromising,
and without losing yourself in the process.

79.58.text:
Follow me inside and let's
get going.

83.98.text:
If you're anything like me then your
relationship probably started out

87.97.text: as a series a magical moments.

94.64.text: And your stomach doing flip-flops just at the thought of seeing him or her, right?

98.94.text:
You felt so loved, and you felt so
wanted, appreciated, and needed, right?

103.60.text: You were joined at the hip.

107.62.text: A terrible thing began to happen...

109.26.text: That feeling of falling in love began to fade away...

113.26.text: and you started to realize just how different you were from your partner

117.01.text:
and perhaps how much of yourself you've
sacrificed

120.15.text:
in order to be in the relationship with your
partner.

123.28.text: Now the little things that you used to love about your partner begin to annoy you...

129.74.text: you're arguing about the dumbest things.

131.82.text:
You've entered what we call the Power
Struggle stage.

136.32.text:
What do we do when we enter the
Power Struggle stage?

137.96.text:
In order to get our needs met... in order to
have that feeling of being in love... again

143.46.text:
We figure, we better go about
changing our partner

146.65.text:
to be more like they used to be, and to
be more like us. Right?

151.04.text:
If you've ever
tried to change anybody before

153.30.text: you've probably noticed that it never works.

155.70.text: So both you and your partner are equally trying to change each other

159.92.text:
And before you know it, the relationship
that was once this safe haven of love

163.85.text: now becomes this place that's full of uncertainty

167.14.text: and were you feel like you have to walk on eggshells around your partner.

172.28.text: just for being the person that you are.

175.16.text: When this happens we begin to feel disconnected.

178.06.text:
Once we begin to feel disconnected
we usually do one of two things:

181.27.text:
We either become needy and try to
reconnect with our partner

184.74.text:
or we become shut down and need space
and want to withdrawal.

189.40.text: Does any of this sound familiar?

193.96.text:
If you can relate to anything I've
just shared, I've got two things I want to say to you

198.02.text:
One is: "Your normal, and it's not your
fault."

201.72.text:
Every relationship goes through this
Power Struggle stage

205.76.text:
when you leave the Romance Stage on the
way to stability

211.10.text: There's only one way and that's through it.

215.76.text: Paradoxically, in order to learn to love you need to learn to fall out of love first.

220.86.text:
And this is just a natural
stage you're going through.

223.80.text:
If you educate yourself about how to get
through the Power Struggle stage

231.66.text:
opportunity for romance,
intimacy and connection.

235.02.text:
That's way beyond anything
you could've experienced back here

239.82.text: How is it that we can go on one hand

242.94.text: being head over heels in love with our partner?

245.44.text:
to on the other hand feeling like our
partner's causing us pain in the relationship?

249.84.text:
One reason could be: That relationships
go through five predictable stages.

254.76.text:
As identified by Dr. Susan Campbell in
her study of hundreds of couples.

258.82.text:
The first stage is called the
Romance stage.

264.93.text:
we fall in love with the single most
incompatible person for us, in the universe.

272.01.text:
of causing us the most pain and least
capable of meeting our primary human needs.

279.38.text: It turns out that we human beings are no different from anything else in nature.

283.64.text: We're either growing or we're dying.

285.52.text:
Of course nature wants us to
grow.

287.95.text:
So nature makes us fall in love with the
most incompatible person in the Universe.

292.72.text: The person most able and capable

295.44.text: of making our worst nightmares come true.

300.32.text:
Because that person is going to be
the most capable of pushing our buttons

303.71.text: and forcing us to grow and expand in our lives.

307.90.text:
They're the perfect
person to insure our growth.

312.78.text: this person was the most incompatible person in the Universe for us

316.08.text: We would run as fast as possible for the hills

323.68.text:
Yep! That's the only way we could
possibly fall in love

325.88.text: with the most incompatible person in the Universe.

327.99.text:
Your brain releases a series of
chemicals like Phenylethylamine and Oxytocin

333.13.text:
That have you fall in love so you can
only see your partner

338.98.text: You would only focus in the Romance Stage

341.14.text: on how you and your partner the same

344.90.text: You'll do anything to please your partner

351.64.text: If you weren't you'd run a mile, right?

354.18.text: What happens is that this drug induced high

357.32.text: lasts for anywhere between two months and two years

360.88.text:
and probably an average
four to six-months

362.83.text: before it begins to wear off.

364.48.text: And when it begins to wear off, you have what I like to call a "love hangover".

369.06.text:
You wake up in bed
with the most incompatible person in the Universe

374.54.text: AND the Power Struggle stage begins.

379.40.text:
And this is where the highest percentage
of first marriage divorce's happen

382.68.text: Usually, around the three to four-year into the relationship mark.

387.33.text:
What ends up happening is that once your
brain stops releasing the oxytocin,

391.57.text: and the dopamine, and all these beautiful drugs,

393.77.text:
you wake up and you realize just how
much of yourself you sacrificed in order

397.64.text: to be in a relationship with this person.

399.70.text:
And now you want yourself back!
You want to reclaim your independence

404.72.text:
So you enter into this
kind of tug-of-war...

407.64.text:
This battle of wills with your
partner

410.02.text:
trying to be in a relationship and yet
still be independent.

414.06.text:
And what happens is because
most couples

416.51.text: - ninety-nine percent of them, I reckon -

418.49.text: Are not educated around how to navigate conflict.

422.38.text:
How to actually communicate and how to deal
with this Power Struggle stage

425.57.text:
They end up dealing with it in one of
two dysfunctional ways:

429.00.text: They either breakup or they survive.

432.90.text:
usually happens with people who have
been kind of serial daters.

436.20.text: They go round, and round, and round in the Romance stage.

438.76.text: Falling in love with that feeling of being in love

440.26.text:
in a drug induced high of being a
drug addict.

442.68.text:
And I like to say "The only difference
between a drug addict and falling in love

445.96.text: is that falling in love is legal".

447.96.text:
And they fall in love with
 this feeling of being high on love

451.66.text:
to then, end up being serial daters.
The minute they hit the Power Struggle stage

455.25.text: they run away from their relationship

458.12.text:
The second way
people deal with the Power Struggle stage

464.18.text:
In that they usually
resigned themselves to compromise

469.82.text:
And they give up what they
really want in order to be with their partner

472.96.text: Of course, the relationship emotionally dies.

475.18.text:
They die internally.
 I've been there and done this in the past too.

478.61.text:
And then their sex life dies as well.
Often this ends up in infidelity or...

483.18.text:
the partner's just eventually growing
apart and...

486.15.text:
the relationship breaking up in the end...
OR the relationship surviving a lifetime of pain.

491.76.text:
When the Power Struggle
 happened to me in my relationship

494.16.text: I was caught completely off guard

497.19.text:
We've gone so quickly in a matter of months
from being head over heels in love

500.47.text:
to being in conflict and fighting with
each other.

502.73.text: It seems we couldn't have a conversation

505.44.text:
without it being blown out of proportion
into an argument.

510.06.text: Because I've been a seminar leader who'd helped thousands of people

512.90.text:
all around the world
transform their lives.

515.39.text:
And yet I couldn't seem to accomplish
the simple task

518.66.text:
of getting the woman that I loved to
respond to me in a way that

522.28.text:
had us feel connected and in love with
each other.

531.42.text:
and she moved to another
country.

535.30.text:
I was shocked and caught completely off
guard.

538.28.text: I decided that this woman was my soulmate

540.92.text:
and I was going to do whatever I could
to get her back

545.34.text: So being the geek that I am...

548.06.text: I went and I studied with successful couples who've gotten through the Power Struggle stage and have done

553.54.text:
built a lifetime of love.
 I started studying communication skills

557.69.text:
I started studying conflict resolution.
And I came up

561.33.text:
with an alternative to the first two
options of breaking up

566.40.text: I like to call this taking the third option.

568.79.text:
The option that most couples don't even know about,
let alone take.

574.36.text:
Involves learning how to love
consciously.

578.85.text:
Involves, instead of seeing your partner
as the most incompatible person in the world

583.50.text:
you start to see them as the most
qualified person to help you grow

588.51.text:
instead of your relationship just being
something that makes you happy and

592.47.text:
you transform your relationship into a
crucible that allows you to grow and

599.61.text:
And in order to accomplish all of this you're
going to need to learn some skills

602.81.text: that you definitely weren't taught by your parents

605.33.text: or by your teachers at school.

607.32.text: Certainly, that's what I had to do.

610.64.text:
It took us six months of negotiating our
differences

613.56.text: before she phoned me up one day and said:

616.42.text:
"Bruce, nobody makes me feel as loved and
as accepted as you do.

621.82.text:
I love you and I want to spend
the rest of my life with you".

625.26.text:
As you can imagine that was the
happiest day of my life.

629.41.text: And we didn't get there by accident

632.61.text:
Do we still fight? Do we still have
arguments?

637.34.text:
But they never turn into
them mudslinging matches that they use to.

643.08.text: They turn into opportunities for us to become more intimately connected.

647.90.text:
Through every one
of our arguments now, we're able to turn it around

652.35.text:
so that that cycle of repeating the same
arguments over and over again

656.45.text:
stops happening. 
And we start to getting arguments complete.

660.21.text:
So once you've learned to fight in a way
that has both of you win

664.01.text: you enter into the Stability Stage.

666.22.text: And this is a beautiful stage were you can take  a deep breath

669.86.text:
and relax... as the romance from the Romance
stage returns

674.15.text: but in a deeper more mature way.

679.12.text:
And you realize that you're never going to
change your partner,

682.08.text: and they're never going to change you,

683.59.text:
and you've given up even trying to do so, 
and you're happy to accept them

686.97.text: just the way that they are.

688.58.text:
In this stage if you master the
communication skills and you

694.73.text:
you move on to the next stage which is
the Commitment Stage.

697.44.text: If you don't master those skills and you don't learn that mutual respect

700.76.text: you go back to the Power Struggle stage,

702.60.text:
round and round and round and round.
Until you.... DIE.

706.98.text:
Not a pretty picture, but that's how
most relationships end up and that's why

710.38.text: we have a divorce rate that's higher than 50 percent

713.60.text: Let's take a look at the Commitment Stage.

716.64.text:
In this stage you choose your partner
just as they are.

720.61.text:
You begin to experience a beautiful
balance of fun,

727.86.text:
And you can honestly say to your
partner:

730.50.text: "I love loving you just as you are. Flaws and all"

735.08.text:
This is the first stage
where

737.31.text:
you're really ready to make a commitment
and get married

741.41.text:
or do whatever your version of that is.
Perhaps do a

744.12.text:
spiritual partnership commitment.
Unfortunately, most couples get married

749.70.text:
in the Romance Stage when they're
COMPLETELY high on drugs

753.60.text: and they have no idea who each other are.

755.68.text:
And they have no idea how to navigate through conflict
when it happens.

760.24.text: And then they wake up one day, and they're trapped in this marriage,

762.52.text: and before they know it they've gotten kids

764.38.text: and they don't know how to navigate it.

765.84.text: This stage of the Commitment Stage

768.92.text:
is the first stage where you're really ready to
make an explicit commitment to your partner

773.80.text:
And if you do... and you do it correctly,
you end up moving to the next stage

777.83.text: which is called the Bliss Stage.

780.09.text:
And in the Bliss Stage the two of you
as a team

783.83.text:
go out into the world and you move beyond
your relationship,

786.79.text: and your relationship as a third unit actually becomes a gift

791.22.text:
that goes out into the world and makes a
difference together.

794.24.text: Perhaps you're working on a project together.

796.30.text:
Perhaps you're doing something in your
community together.

798.62.text:
Perhaps you start a business together.  
Whatever the case may be, your relationship

802.86.text:
serves the world as a gift and you get
to make a difference together.

807.11.text:
There you have it! 
 The five stages of relationship: Romance

810.45.text:
Power Struggle, Stability, Commitment and
Bliss

813.86.text:
Now, which stage are you at? 
Tell the truth to yourself.

In the next video I'm gonna teach you

I'm gonna teach you two myths that if you

I'm going to teach you two mindsets for de-

833.22.text:
when you're fighting or arguing with

844.04.text:
of having the same arguments over and

848.18.text: the actual issue at its root.
